{{other uses}} [[File:Monroe doctrine.jpg|thumb|A 1912 newspaper cartoon highlighting the [[United States]]' influence in [[Latin America]] following the [[Monroe Doctrine]].]]
In the field of [[international relations]], a '''sphere of influence''' ('''SOI''') is a spatial region or concept division over which a state or organization has a level of cultural, economic, military, or political exclusivity, accommodating to the interests of powers outside the borders of the state that controls it.
While there may be a formal alliance or other treaty obligations between the influenced and influencer, such formal arrangements are not necessary and the influence can often be more of an example of [[soft power]]. Similarly, a formal alliance does not necessarily mean that one country lies within another's sphere of influence. High levels of exclusivity have historically been associated with higher levels of conflict.
In more extreme cases, a country within the "sphere of influence" of another may become a subsidiary of that state and serve in effect as a satellite state or de facto colony. The system of spheres of influence by which powerful nations intervene in the affairs of others continues to the present. It is often analyzed in terms of [[superpower]]s, [[great power]]s, and/or [[middle power]]s.
Sometimes portions of a single country can fall into two distinct spheres of influence. In the colonial era the [[buffer state]]s of [[Iran]] and [[Thailand]], lying between the empires of [[United Kingdom|Britain]]/[[Russia]] and Britain/[[France]] respectively, were divided between the spheres of influence of the imperial [[power (international)|powers]]. Likewise, after [[World War II]], [[Germany]] was divided into four [[Allied-occupied Germany|occupation zones]], which later consolidated into [[West Germany]] and [[East Germany]], the former a member of NATO and the latter a member of the [[Warsaw Pact]].
The term is also used to describe non-political situations, e.g., a [[shopping mall]] is said to have a sphere of influence which designates the geographical area where it dominates the [[retail trade]].
==Historical remnants== [[File:Map of colonial Africa in 1897.jpg|thumbnail|right|A map of colonial Africa in 1897 showing the European "sphere[s] of influence".]] Many areas of the world are considered to have inherited culture from a previous sphere of influence, that while perhaps today halted, continues to share the same culture. Examples include the [[Anglosphere]], [[Arab World]], [[Eurosphere]], [[Francophonie]], [[Françafrique]], [[Germanic languages|Germanosphere]], [[Greater India|Indosphere]], [[Legacy of the Roman Empire|Latin Europe]]/[[Latin America]], [[Lusophone|Lusophonie]], [[Pan-Turkism|Turkosphere]], [[Chinese cultural sphere]], [[Slavisphere]], [[Hispanophone]], [[Malay World]], as well as many others.
==New Imperialism era== An example of spheres of influence was China in the late 19th and early 20th Century, when Britain, France, Germany, and Russia (later replaced by Japan) had de facto control over large swaths of territory. These were taken by means of military attacks or threats to force Chinese authorities to sign [[unequal treaty|unequal treaties]] and very long term "leases".<ref>[http://historyworldsome.blogspot.com/2013/12/spheres-of-influence-in-china.html Spheres of Influence in China ]</ref>
[[File:Spheres of influence new.png|thumb|Approximate demarcation of spheres of influence, post-1905, when [[Russo-Japanese War|Japan seized portions of the Russian sphere]]]] In December 1897 German [[Kaiser Wilhelm II]] declared his intent to seize territory in China, precipitating the scramble to demarcate zones of influence in China. The German government acquired, in [[Shandong]] province, exclusive control over developmental loans, mining, and railway ownership,<ref>{{cite book |last1=Jeans |first1=Roger B. |title=Democracy and Socialism in Republican China: The Politics of Zhang Junmai (Carsun Chang), 1906-1941 |date=1997 |publisher=Rowman & Littlefield |isbn=0847687074 |page=28}}</ref> while Russia gained, in addition to the previous tax exemption for trade in [[Mongolia]] and [[Xinjiang]],<ref>{{cite book|last=Paine|first=S. C. M.|title=Imperial Rivals: China, Russia, and Their Disputed Frontier|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=zMrx5Rw5n0AC&pg=PA162|accessdate=22 February 2018|year=1996|publisher=M.E. Sharpe|isbn=9781563247248|pages=162|chapter=Chinese Diplomacy in Disarray: The Treaty of Livadia}}</ref> economic powers similar to Germany's over [[Fengtian Province|Fengtian]], [[Jilin]] and [[Heilongjiang]] provinces. France gained a sphere over [[Yunnan]], [[Guangxi]] and [[Guangdong]] provinces, [[Empire of Japan|Japan]] over [[Fujian]] province, and the British Empire over the whole [[Yangtze River]] Valley and [[Treaty of Lhasa|Tibet]].<ref>[http://www.tibetjustice.org/materials/treaties/treaties10.html Convention Between Great Britain and Tibet (1904)]</ref> Only [[Kingdom of Italy|Italy]]'s request for [[Zhejiang]] province was declined by the Chinese government.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Lo Jiu-Hwa |first1=Upshur |title=Encyclopedia of World History, Ackerman-Schroeder-Terry-Hwa Lo, 2008: Encyclopedia of World History Volume 7 of Encyclopedia of World History |date=2008 |publisher=Fact on File Publishing, Inc Bukupedia |pages=87-88}}</ref> These do not include the lease and [[concession territory|concession territories]] where the foreign powers had full authority.
In 1902, [[Winston Churchill]] gave a speech regarding the division of China by the great powers, where he declared that "we shall have to take the Chinese in hand and regulate them", "I believe in the ultimate partition of China" and "the Aryan stock is bound to triumph".<ref>[http://www.winstonchurchill.org/publications/finest-hour/finest-hour-159/wsc-a-midnight-interview-1902 Speech and interview at the University of Michigan, 1902.]</ref>
The Russian government militarily occupied their zone, imposed their law and schools, seized mining and logging privileges, settled their citizens, and even established their municipal administration on several cities,<ref>{{cite book |last1=Shan |first1=Patrick Fuliang |title=The Development of the North Manchuria Frontier, 1900-1931 |date=2003 |publisher=McMaster University |location=Hamilton, Ontario |page=13}}</ref> the latter without Chinese consent.<ref>{{cite book |last1=Shan |first1=Patrick Fuliang |title=Taming China's Wilderness: Immigration, Settlement and the Shaping of the Heilongjiang Frontier, 1900-1931 |date=2016 |publisher=Routledge |isbn=1317046846 |page=154}}</ref>
The powers (and the United States) might have their own courts, post offices, commercial institutions, railroads, and gunboats in what was on paper Chinese territory. However, the foreign powers and their control in some cases could have been exaggerated; the local government persistently restricted further encroachment.<ref>Patrick Fuliang Shan, “What was the ‘Sphere of Influence’? A Study of Chinese Resistance to the Russian Empire in North Manchuria, 1900-1917,” ''The Chinese Historical Review'', (Fall 2006, vol. 13, no. 2), pp.271-291.</ref> The system ended after the [[Second World War]].
[[File:Map Iran 1900-en.png|thumb|Delimitation of British and Russian influence in Iran]] In the [[Anglo-Russian Convention]] of 1907, Britain and Russia partitioned Persia ([[Iran]]) into spheres of influence, with the Russians gaining recognition for influence over most of northern Iran, and Britain establishing a zone in the Southeast.<ref>British Documents on the Origins of the War 1898-1914, Volume IV, The Anglo-Russian Rapprochement 1903-7. Edited by G.P. Gooch and H Temperley. Her Majesty's Stationary Office, London 1929. p618-621. [https://archive.org/stream/britishdocuments04greabyu#page/626/mode/2up Appendix IV - Revised Draft of Agreement Concerning Persia, Sent to Sir A. Nicholson by Sir Edward Grey on June 6, 1907 ]</ref><ref>[http://avalon.law.yale.edu/20th_century/angrusen.asp Yale Law School: "Agreement concerning Persia" (in English)]</ref>
For Siam ([[Thailand]]), Britain and France signed an agreement in 1904 whereby the British recognised a French sphere of influence to the east of the River Menam's ([[Chao Phraya River]]) basin; in turn, the French recognised British influence over the territory to the west of the Menam basin and west of the Gulf of Thailand. Both parties disclaimed any idea of annexing Siamese territory.<ref>{{cite wikisource | title=Declaration between the United Kingdom and France concerning Siam, Madagascar, and the New Hebrides | year=1904 | publisher=Governments of Great Britain and the French Republic}}</ref>
==United States== {{see also|Foreign relations of the United States|Carter Doctrine|Monroe Doctrine}} [[Alexander Hamilton]], first [[U.S. Secretary of the Treasury]], aimed for the United States to establish a sphere of influence in North America.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://history.state.gov/milestones/1801-1829/monroe|title=Monroe Doctrine, 1823|last=|first=|date=April 6, 2016|website=Office of the Historian|publisher=United States Department of State|access-date=March 26, 2016}}</ref> Hamilton, writing in the [[Federalist Papers]], harboured ambitions for the U.S. to rise to world power status and gain the strength to expel European powers from the Americas, taking on the mantle of regional dominance among American nations, although most of the New World were European colonies during that period.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Morison|first=S.E.|date=February 1924|title=The Origins of the Monroe Doctrine|jstor=2547870|journal=Economica|doi=10.2307/2547870|pmid=}}</ref>
This doctrine was formalised under President [[James Monroe]], who asserted that the New World was to be established as a Sphere of influence, removed from European encroachment. As the U.S. emerged as a world power, few nations dared to trespass on this sphere.<ref name="Brit1">{{cite book |title= New Encyclopædia Britannica |edition= 15th |publisher= Encyclopædia Britannica |volume= 8 |page= 269 |isbn= 1-59339-292-3}}</ref>
As of 2018, Secretary of State [[Rex Tillerson]] continued to refer to the Monroe doctrine to tout the United States as the region's preferred trade partner over other nations such as China.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Gramer|first1=Robbie|title=Tillerson Praises Monroe Doctrine, Warns Latin America of 'Imperial' Chinese Ambitions|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/2018/02/02/tillerson-praises-monroe-doctrine-warns-latin-america-off-imperial-chinese-ambitions-mexico-south-america-nafta-diplomacy-trump-trade-venezuela-maduro/|website=Foreign Policy|publisher=The Slate Group}}</ref>
==World War II== For another example, during the height of its existence in World War II, the [[Japanese Empire]] had quite a large sphere of influence. The Japanese government directly governed events in [[Korea]], [[Vietnam]], [[Taiwan]], and parts of Mainland [[China]]. The "[[Greater East Asia Co-Prosperity Sphere]]" could thus be quite easily drawn on a map of the [[Pacific Ocean]] as a large "bubble" surrounding the islands of [[Japan]] and the [[Asia]]n and Pacific nations it controlled.
===Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact=== According to a secret protocol attached to the [[Molotov-Ribbentrop pact]] of 1939 (revealed only after Germany's defeat in 1945), [[Northern Europe|Northern]] and [[Eastern Europe]] were divided into [[Nazi]] and [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] spheres of influence.<ref name="mrtext">[http://www.fordham.edu/halsall/mod/1939pact.html ''Text of the Nazi-Soviet Non-Aggression Pact''], executed August 23, 1939</ref> In the North, [[Finland]], [[Estonia]], and [[Latvia]] were assigned to the Soviet sphere.<ref name="mrtext"/> [[Poland]] was to be partitioned in the event of its "political rearrangement"—the areas east of the [[Narev]], [[Vistula]], and [[San River]]s going to the Soviet Union while Germany would occupy the west.<ref name="mrtext"/> [[Lithuania]], adjacent to [[East Prussia]], would be in the German sphere of influence, although a second secret protocol agreed in September 1939 assigned Lithuania to the USSR.<ref name="christie">Christie, Kenneth, ''Historical Injustice and Democratic Transition in Eastern Asia and Northern Europe: Ghosts at the Table of Democracy'', RoutledgeCurzon, 2002, {{ISBN|0-7007-1599-1}}</ref> Another clause of the treaty stipulated that [[Bessarabia]], then part of [[Romania]], would join the [[Moldavian Autonomous Soviet Socialist Republic|Moldovan ASSR]] and become the [[Moldovan SSR]] under the control of Moscow.<ref name="mrtext"/> The Soviet invasion of [[Bukovina]] on 28 June 1940 violated the Molotov-Ribbentrop Pact, as it went beyond the Soviet sphere of influence as agreed with the Axis.<ref>Brackman, Roman The Secret File of Joseph Stalin: A Hidden Life (2001) p. 341</ref> The USSR continued to deny the existence of the Pact's protocols until after the [[dissolution of the USSR]] when the Russian government fully acknowledged the existence and authenticity of the secret protocols.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Etkind|first1=Alexander|last2=Finnin|first2=Rory|last3=Blacker|first3=Uilleam |author4=Julie Fedor |author5=Simon Lewis |author6=Maria Mälksoo |author7=Matilda Mroz|title=Remembering Katyn|year=2013|publisher=John Wiley & Sons|isbn=9780745662961}}</ref>
===End of World War II=== From 1941 and the [[Operation Barbarossa|German attack on the Soviet Union]], the [[Allies of World War II|Allied Coalition]] operated on the unwritten assumption that the Western Powers and the Soviet Union had each its own sphere of influence. The presumption of the US-British and Soviet unrestricted rights in their respective spheres started causing difficulties as the Nazi-controlled territory shrank and the allied powers successively liberated other states. The wartime spheres lacked a practical definition and it had never been determined if a dominant allied power was entitled to unilateral decisions only in the area of military activity, or could also force its will regarding political, social and economic future of other states. This overly informal system backfired during the late stages of the war and afterwards, when it turned out that the Soviets and the [[Western Bloc|Western Allies]] had very different ideas concerning the administration and future development of the liberated regions and of Germany itself.<ref name="Davies Victory 172-174">[[Norman Davies]], ''[[Europe at War 1939–1945: No Simple Victory]]'', pp. 172-174. [[Penguin Books]], New York 2006, {{ISBN|978-0-14-311409-3}}</ref>
==Cold War== [[File:Soviet empire 1960.png|thumb|Greatest extent of Soviet influence, before the [[Sino-Soviet Split]]]] During the [[Cold War]] the [[Baltic states]], [[Central Europe]], some countries in [[Eastern Europe]], [[Cuba]], [[Laos]], [[Vietnam]], [[North Korea]], and, until the [[Sino-Soviet split]], the [[People's Republic of China]], among other countries at various times, were said to lie under the [[Soviet sphere of influence]]. [[Western Europe]], [[Oceania]], [[Japan]], and [[South Korea]], among other places, were often said to lie under the sphere of influence of the [[United States]]. However, the level of control exerted in these spheres varied and was not absolute. For instance, France and Great Britain were able to [[Suez Crisis|act independently to invade]] (with [[Israel]]) the [[Suez Canal]] (they were later forced to withdraw by joint U.S. and Soviet pressure). Later, France was also able to withdraw from the military arm of the [[North Atlantic Treaty Organisation]] (NATO). Cuba often took positions that put it at odds with its Soviet ally, including momentary alliances with the People's Republic of China, economic reorganizations, and providing support for insurgencies in Africa and the Americas without prior approval from the Soviet Union. {{citation needed|date=March 2011}}
With the end of the Cold War, the Eastern Bloc fell apart, effectively ending the Soviet sphere of influence. Then in 1991, the Soviet Union collapsed, replaced by the [[Russian Federation]] and several other [[Post-Soviet states|ex-Soviet Republics]] who became independent states.
==1990s to present== {{see also|Foreign relations of Russia}} After the fall of the Soviet Union, the countries of Eastern Europe, the Caucasus, and Central Asia that became independent were often portrayed as part of the Russian Federation's "sphere of influence". According to Ulrich Speck, writing for ''Carnegie Europe'', "After the breakup of the Soviet Union, the West's focus was on Russia. Western nations implicitly treated the post-Soviet countries (besides the Baltic states) as Russia's sphere of influence."<ref name=Carnegie141209>{{cite news |url= http://carnegieeurope.eu/2014/12/09/eu-must-prepare-for-cold-peace-with-russia |title= The EU Must Prepare for a Cold Peace With Russia |first= Ulrich |last= Speck |work= Carnegie Europe |date= 9 December 2014 }}</ref>
In 1997, [[NATO]] and Russia signed the ''Founding Act on Mutual Relations, Cooperation and Security'', stating the "aim of creating in Europe a common space of security and stability, without dividing lines or spheres of influence limiting the sovereignty of any state."<ref name=FoundingAct>{{cite web |url= http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natolive/official_texts_25468.htm |title= Founding Act on Mutual Relations, Cooperation and Security between NATO and the Russian Federation signed in Paris, France |publisher= NATO |date= 27 May 1997 }}</ref>
In 2009, Russia asserted that the [[European Union]] desires a sphere of influence and that the [[Eastern Partnership]] is "an attempt to extend" it.<ref name=EUO090321/> In March 2009, Sweden's foreign minister [[Carl Bildt]] stated that "The Eastern Partnership is not about spheres of influence. The difference is that these countries themselves opted to join".<ref name=EUO090321>{{cite news |url= https://euobserver.com/foreign/27827 |title=EU expanding its 'sphere of influence,' Russia says |first= Valentina |last= Pop |work= [[EUObserver]] |date= 21 March 2009 }}</ref>
Following the 2008 [[Russo-Georgian War]], [[Václav Havel]] and other former central and eastern European leaders signed an open letter stating that Russia had "violated the core principles of the [[Helsinki Final Act]], the [[Charter of Paris]]... -all in the name of defending a sphere of influence on its borders."<ref name=GW090715/> In April 2014, NATO stated that "Contrary to [the Founding Act], Russia now appears to be attempting to recreate a sphere of influence by seizing a part of Ukraine, maintaining large numbers of forces on its borders, and demanding, as Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov recently stated, that “Ukraine cannot be part of any bloc.”"<ref name=NATO140512>{{cite web |url= http://www.nato.int/cps/en/natolive/topics_109141.htm |title= Russia’s accusations - setting the record straight, Fact Sheet - April 2014 |publisher= NATO |date= 12 May 2014 }}</ref> Criticising Russia in November 2014, German Chancellor [[Angela Merkel]] said that "old thinking about spheres of influence, which runs roughshod over international law" put the "entire European peace order into question".<ref name=EUO141117>{{cite news |url= https://euobserver.com/foreign/126540 |title= Merkel: Russia cannot veto EU expansion |first= Andrew |last= Rettman |work= [[EUobserver]] |date= 17 November 2014 }}</ref> In January 2017, British Prime Minister [[Theresa May]] said, "We should not jeopardise the freedoms that President Reagan and Mrs Thatcher brought to Eastern Europe by accepting President Putin's claim that it is now in his sphere of influence."<ref>{{cite news |url= http://www.businessinsider.com/full-text-theresa-mays-speech-to-the-republican-congress-of-tomorrow-conference-2017-1 |title= FULL TEXT: Theresa May's speech to the Republican 'Congress of Tomorrow' conference |publisher= Business Insider |date= 26 January 2017 |archiveurl= https://web.archive.org/web/20170127112956/http://www.businessinsider.com/full-text-theresa-mays-speech-to-the-republican-congress-of-tomorrow-conference-2017-1 |archivedate= 27 January 2017 |deadurl= no }}</ref>
==Corporations== In corporate terms, the sphere of influence of a [[business]], organization or group can show its power and influence in the decisions of other businesses/organizations/groups. Influence shows in several ways, such as in size, frequency of visits, etc. In most cases, a company described as "bigger" has a larger sphere of influence.
For example, the software company [[Microsoft]] has a [[Embrace,_extend,_and_extinguish|large sphere of influence]] in the market of [[operating system]]s; any entity wishing to sell a software product may weigh up compatibility with Microsoft's products as part of a marketing plan.{{citation needed|date=May 2012}}
In another example, retailers wishing to make the most profits must ensure they open their stores in the correct location. This is also true for shopping centers that, to reap the most profits, must be able to attract customers to their vicinity.{{citation needed|date=November 2015}}
There is no defined scale measuring such spheres of influence. However, one can evaluate the spheres of influence of two shopping centers by seeing how far people are prepared to travel to each shopping center, how much time they spend in its vicinity, how often they visit, the order of goods available, etc.{{citation needed|date= November 2015}}
==Other examples== [[File:Great Game cartoon from 1878.jpg|thumb|An 1878 British cartoon about [[The Great Game]] between the [[United Kingdom]] and [[Russia]] over influence in [[Central Asia]]]] For historical and current examples of significant battles over spheres of influence see:
:* [[The Great Game]] :* [[Geostrategy in Central Asia]]

[[File:Surya Majapahit Diagram.svg|thumb|right|300px|The diagram of Surya Majapahit shows the arrangements of Hindu deities each resided in main cardinal points.]]
'''Surya Majapahit''' (The Sun of Majapahit) is the emblem commonly found in ruins dated from the [[Majapahit]] era. The emblem commonly took the form of an eight-pointed [[sun]] ray with the rounded part in the center depicting [[Hindu]] deities. The emblem might have taken the form of a [[cosmology|cosmological]] diagram haloed by typical "Surya Majapahit" sun rays,<ref>{{cite book | author= Bullough Nigel,| title= Historic East Java, Remains in Stone, 50th Anniversary of Indonesia Commemorative Edition | publisher = ADLine Communications | year= 1995| location =Jakarta| page =109 }}</ref> or a simple circle with typical sun rays. Because of the popularity of this sun emblem during the Majapahit era, it is suggested that the sun emblem served as the imperial symbol or [[emblem]] of the Majapahit empire.
==Hindu deities== The most common depiction of Surya Majapahit consists of the images of nine deities and eight sun rays. The round center of the sun depicting nine Hindu gods called ''[[Guardians of the directions|Dewata Nawa Sanga]]''. The major gods in the center is arranged in eight cardinal points around one god in the center. The arrangements are: *Center: [[Shiva]] *East: [[Isvara]] *West: [[Shiva|Mahadeva]] *North: [[Vishnu]] *South: [[Brahma]] *Northeast: [[Shiva|Sambhu]] *Northwest: [[Shiva|Sangkara]] *Southeast: [[Maheshvara|Mahesora]] *Southwest: [[Rudra]]
The minor deities located at the outer rim of the sun, symbolized by eight shining sun rays: *East: [[Indra]] *West: [[Varuna]] *North: [[Kubera]] *South: [[Yama]] *Northeast: [[Ishana|Isana]] *Northwest: [[Vayu]] *Southeast: [[Agni]] *Southwest: [[Nirṛti]]
[[File:Surya Majapahit 2.jpg|thumb|left|The common carving of Surya Majapahit taken from Majapahit temple ruins, Trowulan Museum]]
[[File:Surya Majapahit.jpg|thumb|right|Another render of Surya Majapahit, taken from Majapahit temple ruins, National Museum Jakarta]]
The emblem is rendered in many forms; sometimes it took the form of the circle of deities and sun rays, or just a simple eight-pointed sun ray such as the emblematic Surya Majapahit set into the ceiling of [[Candi Penataran]].<ref>{{cite book | author= Bullough Nigel,| title= Historic East Java, Remains in Stone, 50th Anniversary of Indonesia Commemorative Edition | publisher = ADLine Communications | year= 1995| location =Jakarta| page =91 }}</ref> The deities in the sun arranged as cosmological diagram in the form of a [[mandala]]. Another variation of Surya Majapahit is the eight pointed sun rays with the god of sun [[Surya]] in the center riding celestial horse or chariot. The carving of Surya Majapahit usually can be found on the center ceiling of the [[Garbhagriha]] (inner sanctum) of the temple such as Bangkal, Sawentar, and [[Candi Jawi|Jawi]] temple. Surya Majapahit also can be found on the Stella, carving of [[Halo (religious iconography)|halo]] or [[Aura (paranormal)|aura]] at the back of the statue's head. The carving of Surya Majapahit also commonly found in gravestone dating from Majapahit era, such as the Troloyo cemetery in [[Trowulan]].

page.title: Taxation of the Jews in Europe

revision.text:
'''Taxation of the Jews in Europe''' refers to taxes imposed specifically on [[Jewish]] people in [[Europe]], in addition to the taxes levied on the general population. Special taxation imposed on the Jews by the state or ruler of the territory in which they were living has played an important part in Jewish history.<ref name="Judaica">[https://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/History/ancienttaxation.html Taxation. Encyclopaedia Judaica.] Reproduced by Jewish Virtual Library.</ref> The abolition of special taxes on the Jews followed their admission to civil rights in France and elsewhere in Europe at the end of the 18th and beginning of the 19th centuries.<ref name="Judaica"/>
== In the Roman Empire == The [[Fiscus Judaicus]] ([[Latin]]: "Jewish tax") or "Temple Tax" was a [[tax]] collecting agency instituted to collect the tax imposed on [[Jewish diaspora#Post-Roman Diaspora|Jews]] in the [[Roman Empire]] after the destruction of the [[Second Temple|Temple of Jerusalem]] in 70 CE in favor of the temple of [[Temple of Jupiter Optimus Maximus|Jupiter Capitolinus]] in [[Ancient Rome|Rome]].
The tax was initially imposed by [[Roman Emperor]] [[Vespasian]] as one of the [[Anti-Judaism|measures against Jews]] as a result of the [[First Roman-Jewish War]] of 66–73 CE. Vespasian imposed the tax in the aftermath of the [[First Jewish–Roman War|Jewish revolt]] (Josephus ''BJ'' 7. 218; Dio Cassius 65.7.2). The tax was imposed on all Jews throughout the empire, not just on those who took part in the revolt against Rome. The tax was imposed after the [[destruction of the Second Temple]] in 70 CE in place of the levy (or [[Tithe]]) payable by Jews towards the upkeep of the Temple. The amount levied was two [[denarius|denarii]], equivalent to the one-half of a [[shekel]] that observant Jews had previously paid for the upkeep of the Temple of Jerusalem ({{bibleverse||Exodus|30:13|HE}}). The tax was to go instead to the [[Temple of Capitoline Jupiter]], the major center of [[Religion in ancient Rome|ancient Roman religion]]. The ''fiscus Iudaicus'' was a humiliation for the Jews.{{Citation needed|date=June 2011}} In Rome, a special [[procurator (Roman)|procurator]] known as ''procurator ad capitularia Iudaeorum'' was responsible for the collection of the tax.<ref name="Fiscus">"Fiscus Judaicus", ''Encyclopedia Judaica''</ref> Only those who had abandoned Judaism were exempt from paying it.
== In the Holy Roman Empire == The Jewish populations of Europe were politically insecure and could be easily exploited for the levying of heavy taxes in exchange for official protection. The high interest rates charged by Jews became an illimitable source of tax revenue and Jewish wealth was technically easy to gauge because Jews typically stored their assets in the form of cash or promissory notes.<ref>{{cite book|author=Eberhard Isenmann|editor=Richard Bonney|title=The Rise of the Fiscal State in Europe c.1200-1815|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U24lRLy_qT8C&pg=PA259|date=2 September 1999|publisher=Clarendon Press|isbn=978-0-19-154220-6|pages=259–}}</ref>
The Imperial Tax Register of 1241 was the first register to include taxes on the Jews. The total of the taxes on the Jews listed in the Register amounted to 857 silver marks; the total contribution of all the cities together amounted to 4.290 silver marks. These local taxes served wholly or in part to finance town-building. Not all of the contributions reached the central administration. In contrast, it is clear from the Register that the payments made by the Jews reached the Exchequer in their entirety.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 13–14</ref> The taxes on the Jews were first described as the ’’Jewish Tax’’ in 1330.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 18–19</ref>
The Opferfennig (originally Guldenpfennig) tax was introduced in 1342 by Emperor [[Louis IV the Bavarian]], who ordered all Jews above the age of 12 and possessing 20 gulden to pay one gulden annually for protection. This taxation was 1 florin for every Jew and included assets worth more than 20 florins. Widows were not exempted. King Wenceslas removed the taxable minimum but an exemption for Jews dependent on alms was made later by Sigsmund, who himself levied heavy taxation. Sigsmund taxed a third of the value of Jewish properties. It was represented as a coronation tax as part of Sigsmund's attempts to ascend the throne. Isenmann disagrees and believes it was an innovation sprouted by Archchamberlain Konrad von Weinsberg. By 1433-4 the tax collectors were collecting tax worth a half of Jewish properties.<ref>{{cite book|author=Eberhard Isenmann|editor=Richard Bonney|title=The Rise of the Fiscal State in Europe c.1200-1815|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=U24lRLy_qT8C&pg=PA259|date=2 September 1999|publisher=Clarendon Press|isbn=978-0-19-154220-6|pages=259–}}</ref>
Emperor [[Charles IV, Holy Roman Emperor|Charles IV]] later ordered the income of the Opferfennig tax to be delivered to the archbishop of [[Triers]]. This tax was at some places replaced by an overall communal tax.<ref>[http://www.jewishvirtuallibrary.org/jsource/judaica/ejud_0002_0015_0_15120.html OPFERPFENNIG. Encyclopaedia Judaica]. 2008.</ref>
== Leibzoll ==
The ''[[Leibzoll]]'' or ''Judengeleit'' was a special [[tariff|toll]] which Jews had to pay in most of the European states in the [[Middle Ages]] and up to the beginning of the nineteenth century.<ref>{{Cite book| author=Isidore Singer, Cyrus Adler | title=The Jewish Encyclopedia, Vol. 7 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SzsyAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA669| year=1906| publisher=Funk & Wagnalls Company|page=669}}</ref>
== In Hungary == [[Tolerance tax]] (Toleranzgebührer) was a [[tax]] that was levied against [[Jews]] of [[Hungary]], then part of the [[Austrian Empire]], beginning in 1747.<ref name="jg">JewishGen. Hungary: Assorted Census Records, 1781-1850 [database on-line]. Provo, UT, USA: The Generations Network, Inc., 2008.</ref>
The tax was based on the German statute that a Jew was obliged to pay a certain tax to be "tolerated".<ref>Wine and thorns in Tokay Valley: Jewish life in Hungary : the history of Abaújszántó, by Zahava Szász Stessel, Fairleigh Dickinson Univ Press, 1995, p. 50-51</ref>
== In Poland ==
=== Koło === In 1571 a contract was drafted with regard to the status of the Jews in [[Koło]], in which the city's Christians have undertaken to provide protection to the Jews, in return for which the Jews were required to pay a special annual municipal tax.<ref name="mahler">Mahler, Rafael. [http://www.jewishgen.org/yizkor/kolo/kol008.html "From the near and far past". Some information about the history of the Jews of Koło.]</ref>
In 1729 the Jewish community was required to pay 150 gold coins as an annual poll tax, and in 1738 this sum was increased to 300 gold coins.<ref name="mahler"/>
In 1775 the Polish parliament imposed a special duty on books written in [[Hebrew]] and [[Yiddish]], requiring each book to be stamped by the municipality. Despite heavy penalties imposed on owners of unstamped books, many books were concealed and unstamped.<ref name="mahler"/>
== In Russia == The Russian [[Kosher tax]], known as the ''korobka'', was a tax paid only by Jews for each animal slaughtered in accordance with the [[kashrut]] rules and for each pound of this meat sold.<ref name="ji"/><ref>[http://www.shtetlinks.jewishgen.org/kraziai/history_tax_on_jews.htm Korobka Tax on Kraziai's Jews], Document 49-1-1362 from the Kaunas Archive</ref> It was part of the Russian Jewish "basket tax" or "box tax". Though it was used to refer to a tax on meat or slaughtering, the word ''korobka'' (Russian: коробка) actually means "box" in Russian. The tax came to be called that because Jews paying had to deposit a coin in a box at the kosher slaughterer.<ref name=Diner2001p164>[[Hasia R. Diner|Diner, Hasia R.]] ''Hungering for America: Italian, Irish, and Jewish Foodways in the Age of Migration'', [[Harvard University Press]], 2001, {{ISBN|978-0-674-00605-8}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=zU1WYFWxn74C&pg=PA164 p. 164.]</ref>
According to [[Herman Rosenthal]] and [[Jacob Goodale Lipman]], the tax was "the most burdensome and annoying of the special taxes imposed upon the Jews of Russia by the government".<ref name="ji">[[Herman Rosenthal|Rosenthal, Herman]]; [[Jacob Goodale Lipman|Lipman, J.G.]] [http://www.jewishencyclopedia.com/view.jsp?artid=394&letter=B "Basket-Tax"], ''[[Jewish Encyclopedia]]''.</ref><ref name="Belovinskiĭ2003p357">Leonid Vasilʹevich Belovinskiĭ. ''Энциклопедический словарь российской жизни и истории: XVIII-начало XX в'', Olma Media Group, 2003, {{ISBN|978-5-224-04008-7}} [https://books.google.com/books?id=4W5sUATx57MC&pg=PA357 p. 357.]</ref><ref>[[Simon Dubnow|Dubnow, Simon]]; [[Israel Friedlander|Friedlaender, Israel]]. ''History of the Jews in Russia and Poland'', Avotaynu Inc, 2000 {{ISBN|978-1-886223-11-0}}, [https://books.google.com/books?id=vL60sEf7OPoC&pg=PA227&lpg=PA227 p. 227.]</ref> The burden of taxes, and the ''korobka'' in particular, was one of the factors which drove many Jews to abandon the towns and settle in villages or on noblemen estates.<ref>Encyclopaedia Judaica (1971): History, vol. 8, 734</ref>
==In Galicia== Between 1777 and 1784, the Jews of [[Horodenka]], a region on the southeast corner of [[Galicia (eastern Europe)|Galicia]], paid a number of special taxes, including the "protection and [[tolerance tax]]", and the "property and occupation tax". In 1784, the property and occupation tax was replaced with the kosher meat tax.<ref>Gelber, N. M. ''The History of the Jews of Horodenka'', p. 86.</ref>
==In Moldavia== In 1741, Moldavian prince [[Grigore II Ghica|Grigore Ghica]] confirmed the obligation of each Jew to pay the crupca, an indirect tax on kosher meat similar to the Russian ''korobka''.<ref>[http://www.yivoencyclopedia.org/printarticle.aspx?id=925 Iaşi, by Lucian-Zeev Herşcovici ]</ref>
== In Altona and Hamburg == During the period 1641–1842, the [[Jews]] of [[Altona, Hamburg|Altona]] (then a town close to Hamburg) paid specifically Jewish taxes as well as the same taxes as other residents of Altona. The tax burden on the members of the Jewish community was twice as heavy as that on the other residents.
In 1640 the Danish King [[Christian IV]] acquired part of the [[Holstein-Pinneberg|County of Pinneberg]] including Altona.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 25–26</ref> Altona was subsequently granted the rights and status of a town on 23 August 1664.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 53–54</ref>
=== Jews in Hamburg ===
The community was founded principally by Portuguese merchants and was known as the [[Portuguese Jewish community in Hamburg|Portuguese-Jewish Community]], although many of its members were of Spanish-Jewish descent.
These [[Sephardic Jews]], who initially pretended to be persecuted [[Catholic]]s, first came to [[Hamburg]] at the end of the 16th century. They were mostly Portuguese- or Spanish-speaking merchants. In 1621, when the armistice between [[Spain]] and the [[Netherlands]] came to an end, many of the Portuguese Jews moved to Hamburg. They were made welcome, even after the actual situation had become clear; however they were not permitted to establish a cemetery within the city walls. Thanks to the linguistic skills of the Sephardim and their contacts among their co-religionaries they controlled a large sector of the German market in provisions. The Sephardim differed culturally and socially from the Jews who came to Altona, and subsequently also to Hamburg, from the east. These were [[Yiddish Language]] speaking [[Ashkenazim]]. The permanent settlement of the Ashkenazim was opposed by both the [[Senate of Hamburg]] (town council) and the citizens, supported by the Sephardim, who did not wish to see the establishment of a second community in Hamburg. As servants, referred to as tudescos, the Ashkenazi Jews were, de facto, under the protection of the Sephardic Jews.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 91–94</ref>
=== Jews in Altona ===
On 1 August 1641 the Danish king had formally granted the Ashkenazi Jews the privilege of having in Altona, as hitherto, a cemetery and a synagogue, thus providing the basis for the existence of a Jewish community.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 111</ref> Subsequently, the Danish kings promised the Jews personal security, the freedom to practice trade and religious liberties. Some of the Jews living in Hamburg therefore tried to secure the legal protection of the Danish crown in case of any attempt to expel them. In Altona the conditions of residence were favorable, in Hamburg the conditions for trading. These were the reasons for the genesis of the Altona community of Ashkenazi Jews from Hamburg and Altona.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 91</ref> Thanks to immigration from the east, Altona became a center of research and scholarship in Jewish teaching, attracting hundreds of students. The officially recognized [[Beth din|Jewish court of justice]] had a reputation as one of the most distinguished in the whole Jewish world.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 243–244</ref> The Jews did not acquire these privileges freely, but in return for the payment of taxes.
=== Levies on Jews ===
From 1584 to 1639, as in the Middle Ages, the Jews of Altona paid taxes specific to the Jews, but no further taxes. Each Jewish family was required to pay 6 [[rixdollar|Reichstaler]] per year. Under Danish rule this changed: the Jews continued to pay the specifically Jewish taxes plus the same taxes as all other residents.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 135</ref> From 1641 every Jewish family was required to pay 5 Reichstaler in Jewish taxes; in the year when Altona became a town the contribution rose to 6 Reichstaler.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 135, pp. 180–181</ref> With the ordinance of 1641 the Danish king had permitted the Jews [[shechita]]. This privilege too was not cost-free. For the years 1667–1669 we have records of taxes paid by Jewish butchers. According to these the rates were 1 Mark and 8 Schillinge for an ox, 4 Schillinge for a calf and 2 Schillinge for a lamb. These taxes were twice as high as those paid by Christian butchers.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 153, pp. 168–169</ref> From 1681 Individual taxes on the Jews (6 Reichstaler plus the payments made by the Jewish butchers), were replaced by lump-sum payments by the Jewish community.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 156</ref>
From the year 1712 onwards it is possible to calculate the amount of the lump-sum payments made by the Jews. During the period 1712–1818 this amounted to 6 Reichstaler for each Jewish family; 6 Reichstaler was the level that had already been set in 1584. Assuming that a Jewish family consisted of approximately 6 persons, 6 Reichstaler corresponded to 1 Reichstaler for each individual Jew. On top of this 1 Reichstaler, also paid by the other residents, had to be paid.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, pp. 265-266. Meaningful conversion of the face-value can be made for this period since, unlike the paper money of Copenhagen, the silver currency of Altona was stable, p. 50</ref> The tax burden on the members of the Jewish community was twice as heavy as that on the other residents. The influence of this on business practice constituted an obstacle to the granting of civil rights. In the year 1818 the Jewish Elders declared to the community of Altona that they could not, ’’on the one hand, levy specifically Jewish taxes on the members of their community and, on the other hand, encourage our co-religionaries, especially the younger ones, to pursue useful activity. In short: so to improve our condition that we might not seem unworthy to acquire civil rights. The extension – against our wishes - of the taxes on the Jews would be incompatible with the granting of civil rights.’’<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 239</ref> This marks the beginning of the struggle of the Jewish community for emancipation. The Jewish community secured the abolition of taxes on the Jews in the year 1842.<ref>Judenschutzsteuern, p. 199</ref>

'''The Corner House''' is a [[Non-profit organization|not for profit]] [[company limited by guarantee]] founded in 1997 in the [[United Kingdom]]. According to its [[website]], it aims "to support democratic & community movements for environmental & [[social justice]]"<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thecornerhouse.org.uk/about/item.shtml?cmd[402]=x-402-49653|title=About The Corner House|accessdate=2008-04-23|}}</ref>
In 2007, The Corner House and the [[Campaign Against Arms Trade]] sought a [[judicial review]] of the [[Her Majesty's Government|UK Government]]'s discontinuation of an investigation by the [[Serious Fraud Office (UK)|Serious Fraud Office]] into the [[Al-Yamamah_arms_deal|Al Yamamah arms deal]].<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7086171.stm|title= BAE inquiry decision challenged|accessdate=2008-04-23|publisher=[[BBC News Online|BBC News website]]|date=2007-11-09}}</ref> The High Court initially declared the Serious Fraud Office's discontinuation unlawful in April 2008, but this decision was unanimously reversed by the House of Lords in July of the same year.
==Legal analysis== The principle had already been established in ''[[Leila Khaled|Khalid]]'' that where the Crown had no choice, a prosecution could be dropped in the face of an extreme threat.<ref>Corner House (High Court) at 81-83</ref> The question was therefore simply whether the Director of the Serious Fraud Office had done 'all that could reasonably be done had been done to resist the threat'.<ref>Corner House (High Court) at 170-1</ref> In April 2008 the [[High Court of Justice]] ruled that the [[Serious Fraud Office (UK)|Serious Fraud Office]] had acted unlawfully in dropping the investigation for failing to do so.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7339231.stm|title=UK wrong to halt Saudi arms probe|accessdate=2008-04-23|publisher=[[BBC News Online|BBC News website]]|date=2008-04-10}}</ref>
On 30 July of the same year, this decision was unanimously reversed by the House of Lords. They overruled both the factual and principled basis of the High Court's decision. As a matter of principle, they ruled the courts could only declare the decision unlawful if it was outside of the Director's power, not merely unreasonable. Factually, they held that his decision was in any case reasonable.<ref>Corner House (House of Lords) Lord Bingham at 40-1 </ref>
==References== {{reflist}} Judgements:
Corner House (High Court): ''R. (on the application of Corner House Research) v Director of the Serious Fraud Office'' [2008] EWHC 714 (Admin)
Corner House (House of Lords): ''R (On the Application of Corner House Research and Others) v Director of the Serious Fraud Office'' [2008] UKHL 60
==External links== * [http://www.thecornerhouse.org.uk The Corner House]
